etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Carlyle (1795–1881), author, biographer, and historian. From German Philister, specific sense of Philister Philistine from post-classical Latin Philistaeus, Philisteus + German -er

definitions: An unenlightened or uncultured person; = "Philistine"; (specifically in German universities) a townsperson, a non-student.
